Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Tracking trends in the lichen symbiosis: do species interactions drive the latitudinal diversity gradient?
Award.AbstractNarration:
The latitudinal diversity gradient is the pattern in which many species are found in the tropics, near the equator, and fewer species are found outside of the tropics, towards the North and South poles. This pattern is often explained in terms of temperature, climate, or geological conditions. Less frequently, the latitudinal gradient is described in terms of biotic interactions; interactions between different organisms. This research investigates a particular biotic interaction, the lichen symbiosis, along a large environmental gradient from North to South America. Lichens are symbioses (mutually beneficial, long-term, close physical associations) between fungi and algae/cyanobacteria. Though small and often overlooked, lichens can be found in almost every terrestrial environment, making them ideal for investigating biotic interactions across large environmental gradients. This research will focus on the role of symbiosis in driving patterns of diversity, and may improve predictions of how patterns of diversity change in the face of ongoing changes in climate. This research uniquely addresses both partners in the symbiosis, and will increase our knowledge of global biodiversity through the discovery and description of new species and traits. This project will extend the research and training of a doctoral student by supporting research that moves from descriptive pattern to mechanistic process. A workshop on symbioses will be made available to undergraduate students in Michigan, and educational materials for high school classrooms will be offered via the Data Nugget program, promoting the scientific process and potentially recruiting more students to science and technology at the college level.

The biotic interactions hypothesis proposes that in extra-tropical regions, abiotic selective pressures exert a stronger force, whereas in tropical regions, biotic selective pressures exert a stronger force. Furthermore, these biotic interactions lead to moving peaks of adaptation, and coevolutionary races, which further contributes to diversification in the tropics. This research investigates the dynamics of the lichen symbiosis along a latitudinal gradient by sequencing both the fungal and algal partners within five lichen-forming families of fungi found along the latitudinal gradient in order to map patterns of specificity among partners, and to test whether partner switches have resulted in diversification events or range shifts in the lichen symbiosis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many groups of organisms, including flowering plants, butterflies, marine invertebrates, and mammals, follow a pattern of high species richness and diversity around the equator, and decreasing diversity as you go from the equator towards either of the poles. This global phenomenon is known as the latitudinal diversity gradient, and has been observed and investigated by researchers for over two hundred years. Despite this long history, there are still some groups of organisms whose latitudinal diversity gradient has not been investigated, and there is still no scientific consensus on the central mechanism driving this global phenomenon. In this project, we investigated the latitudinal diversity gradient of lichens, a symbiotic association between a fungus and a photosynthetic partner, either algae or cyanobacteria. Symbiosis is the long term and close interaction between two species; without their photosynthetic partners, lichenized fungi cannot survive.

Through a massive field-based project during which the PhD student (the CoPI) visited nine different sites along a 70-degree latitudinal gradient in the Americas, nine hundred trees were surveyed for epiphytic lichen diversity. Data from these surveys supports a latitudinal diversity gradient of lichens, adding them to the list of organisms that follow this global trend. Both the diversity of the host trees that the lichens grow on as well as the amount and pattern of precipitation play an important role. One of the hypotheses of the latitudinal diversity gradient is the biotic interactions hypothesis. According to this hypothesis, we might expect lichens in the tropics to have more specific associations with their photosynthetic partners, and lichens outside of the tropics to be more generalist. Preliminary results do not find patterns of specificity along a latitudinal gradient, even though the communities of photosynthetic partners turn over from one site to the next.

This doctoral dissertation improvement grant achieved multiple education goals, including the training of a PhD student (the CoPI). To her existing knowledge of lichen biology and ecology, she broadened her skill set to include lichen identification and techniques and analyses in next generation sequencing. The CoPI also contributed through this grant to the training of four undergraduate students, and the training of one international field assistant. Results of this project have been disseminated to the general public through activities at Science Festivals, a talk at Biology on Tap, and a Dance Your PhD video. Results have been disseminated to the scientific community through presentations at national and international meetings. The CoPI has successfully defended her PhD dissertation and is now working as a postdoctoral researcher at the Sainsbury Laboratory in the UK.
